Based on the information provided in Document-0, the assertion that "In the UK, drowning affects boys at a higher rate than girls" is not valid. The document explains that ecological studies, such as those that compare the rates of drowning between boys and girls in the UK, are susceptible to the ecological fallacy.
The ecological fallacy refers to the mistake of assuming that patterns observed at the group level (such as the rate of drowning among boys in the UK) will hold true at the individual level (i.e., that a particular boy in the UK will be more likely to drown than a particular girl). This is because ecological studies do not take into account the unique characteristics of individual people within a group, which can lead to incorrect inferences about cause-and-effect relationships.
Therefore, while there may be some truth to the assertion that boys are more likely to drown than girls in the UK, this statement cannot be definitively proven based solely on ecological data. To make more accurate inferences about the relationship between gender and drowning risk, individual-level studies would be necessary to control for factors such as age, swimming ability, and other individual characteristics that can affect drowning risk.

Based on the information provided in Document-0, the assertion that "Thigh-length graduated compression stockings (GCS) did not reduce deep vein thrombosis in patients admitted to hospital who are immobile because of acute stroke" is not supported by the available evidence.

1. The meta-analysis conducted in Document-0 included 15 randomized controlled trials that evaluated the effectiveness of different anticoagulant prophylaxis regimens in preventing catheter-associated deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in patients with central venous catheters.

4. The study did not evaluate the effectiveness of graduated compression stockings in preventing DVT in immobile patients with acute stroke.
